bibl.title: Letter from C.H. Lavinder to Laura Armistead Carter, September 29, 1925

div1.p: Lavinder expresses condolences on the death of Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from C.H. Lavinder to Laura Armistead Carter, September 29, 1925

opener.dateline:
U. S. Marine Hospital,
??? N. Y.
September 29th,

div1.p:
My tardi-
ness in writing this letter is
due to a few days of absence
on leave from which I have
just returned.

In the death of Dr. Carter I
almost feel that I have lost
a second father. For indeed
he was my professional father,
having initiated me - a
green youngster - into the
first principles of clinical Med-
icine and favorably introduced to
me the Public Health Service
as a career for medical men.
To him I owe not only this,
but a great deal wore by
reason of his personal influ-
ence; and the profit and
delight of personal contact
with him during the more
or less formative years of
my professional life will
always remain to me a
happy memory.

I know, at least in a
way, how much he has
meant to you, and I realize
to some extent how Kean
is your loss. Please accept my
sincere sympathy in your sor-
row. It is needless to say
that my feeling is shared
by the entire Service. Another
is won than a mere ex-
pression, it is literally true.
Even though in retirements from
Active Service life he yet
remained a potent influence
& a valued adviser and coun-
sellor. The Service has sus-
tained a great loss.

I wish I could express
to you how real is my
sympathy. Words will hardly
do that. Believe me, that
both Mrs. Lavinder and my-
self have the most complete
sympathy with you in your
grief. We send you our best
wishes and pray the good
Lord may sustain and
comfort you in your great
trial.
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely yours, C H Lavinder Miss Laura Carter,
Washington, D. C.
